revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=February 2018}} {{advert|date=February 2018}} {{Orphan|date=February 2018}} }} {{Infobox magazine | italic title = Smith Journal | title = Smith Journal | image_file = | image_caption = Volume 9 | editor = Chris Harrigan | previous_editor = Nadia Saccardo | category = Men, Culture, Art, Design, Photography, Style, Fashion, | frequency = Quarterly | publisher = [[Morrison Media]] | total_circulation = 32,000<ref>[http://www.smithjournal.com.au/media-kit]</ref> | founded = 2011 | country = Australia | based = Melbourne | language = English | website = {{URL|smithjournal.com.au}} }}
'''''Smith Journal''''' is a quarterly Australian magazine based in Melbourne, and founded in 2011. The publication focuses on history, photography, art, and design, but also features articles on architecture, fashion, science, DIY, adventure, and literature. ''Smith Journal'' is published by Frankie Press,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.frankiepress.com.au/|title=frankie press // frankie magazine // smith journal // Slow|website=www.frankiepress.com.au|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> creators of popular Australian magazine '''''[[Frankie (magazine)|frankie]]'''.'' The magazine is lauded for sharing the same "inquisitive nature, intelligent copy and compelling stories"<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.pedestrian.tv/news/meet-frankies-mens-spinoff-smith-journal/|title=Meet Frankie's Men's Spinoff "Smith Journal" – Pedestrian TV|date=9 August 2011|work=Pedestrian TV|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> as ''frankie''.
== History and profile == ''Smith Journal'' was founded by frankie press editors-at-large Rick Bannister and Louise Bannister as a men’s magazine in the same vein as ''frankie.'' It was designed to attract readers interested in “real people doing real things, guys that are making stuff, creative thinkers, adventurers, whatever.”<ref name=":1" />
The magazine was initially planned to be published on a bi-annual schedule,<ref name="adnews.com.au">{{Cite news|url=http://www.adnews.com.au/adnews/frankie-launches-smith-journal-in-a-leap-of-faith|title=Frankie launches Smith Journal in a leap of faith – AdNews|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> but adopted a quarterly publishing schedule following its positive reception.
Similar to ''frankie,'' the magazine is printed on premium matte paper stock, and marketed as a "bespoke"<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://theconversation.com/why-the-saturday-papers-design-breeds-disappointment-24198|title=Why The Saturday Paper's design breeds disappointment|last=Sadokierski|first=Zoe|work=The Conversation|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en}}</ref> title suitable as both a casual read and coffee table magazine.
''Smith Journal'' is owned and published by niche publisher Morrison Media, parent owners of Frankie Press who also publish ''frankie'' magazine.<ref name=":0" /> Morrison Media moved production of its titles to [[Melbourne]] in February 2014 when it closed its [[Queensland]] based offices.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/frankie-press-co-founders-depart-204965|title=Frankie Press co-founders depart as Morrison Media moves sales hub to Melbourne – Mumbrella|date=7 February 2014|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Later that year, Morrison Media was acquired by Pacific Star Network in November 2014 for $10m AUD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mumbrella.com.au/frankie-publisher-morrison-media-bought-10m-deal-262164|title=Frankie publisher Morrison Media bought out in $10m deal – Mumbrella|date=12 November 2014|work=Mumbrella|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref>
''Smith Journal's'' name is derived from the titles used for professional [[Writer|wordsmiths]] or [[blacksmith]]s; traditional artisans and craftsmen that embody the down-to-earth quality the magazine attempts to emulate.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.scout.com.au/Blog/Smith-Journal---a-smart-new-publication-from-Frankie-Magazine|title=Smith Journal: a smart new publication from Frankie Magazine|work=Scout|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Content == The magazine's somewhat niche content and minimalistic approach to topics is a direct response to the salacious "lad mags" of the magazine industry such as ''[[FHM]]'' and ''[[Zoo Weekly]].'' At the time of ''Smith Journal's'' launch, the men's magazine market largely consisted of [[Popular culture|populist]] focused titles with a very broad target audience such as ''[[Men's Health]]'', or hobby-specific titles dedicated to a singular topic. Instead of attempting to engage as many readers as possible through glossy pages filled with current events topics, the editors of ''Smith Journal'' felt that there was a "gap in the market for guys who felt that their magazines hadn't grown or changed with them."<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/comment/from-zoo-to-smith-journal-are-men-finally-choosing-brains-over-boobs-20140619-zsf9r.html|title=From Zoo to Smith Journal: Are men finally choosing brains over boobs?|last=Watson|first=Meg|date=28 June 2014|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-US}}</ref> According to the founding editor Nadia Saccardo, the magazine was not created with an emphasis on a specific gender, but was instead focused on "unexpected, accessible storytelling coupled with great photography and illustration."<ref name=":3" />
Many of the articles focus on topics and individuals related to history, photography, art and design. Volume 25 profiles photographer Daniel George, whose portfolio consists of household items used for [[target practice]]; an article discussing the cultural re-evaluation of [[Glam metal|1980s hair metal]] music; and an interview with former [[NASA]] scientist Robert Lang who now designs [[origami]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/this-volume|title=Volume 25|date=30 January 2018|access-date=2018-01-30|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180130074538/http://www.smithjournal.com.au/this-volume|archivedate=30 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Previous issues have also included interviews with American musician [[Henry Rollins]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2686-smith-journal-volume-20|title=Volume 20|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> and professional safe-cracker [[Jeff Sitar]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2489-smith-journal-volume-17|title=Volume Seventeen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> an historical article on Soviet rocket architect [[Galina Balashova]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2701-volume-nineteen|title=Volume Nineteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref> and Brazil's illegal [[hot air balloon]] subculture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2385-volume-sixteen|title=Volume Sixteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
The stylistic design of the magazine makes use of a large amount of white space and very [[Minimalism (disambiguation)|minimalistic]] photographs and illustrations with text pairings. Many articles are presented on a stark white background, some without a headline or photo to accompany it. A number of photographs are presented on a [[two-page spread]]. All of the photographs adhere to a similar [[Image editing|editing]] style which includes faded blacks to complement the matte paper they are printed on.
Issues will often include tear-out posters of illustrations or diagrams. For example, Volume 25 features an illustrated diagram of the [[Lunar calendar|2018 lunar calendar]], and Volume 18 included a twenty-sided [[icosahedron]] globe.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/past-volumes/2468-smith-journal-volume-18|title=Volume Eighteen|website=www.smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-30}}</ref>
These content and design choices are intentionally similar in style to ''[[Frankie (magazine)|frankie]],'' another Frankie Press publication. Editor-at-Large Louise Bannister stated that "they're from the same family – lots of white space…but the treatment of pictures and text is a little different."<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=https://www.broadsheet.com.au/melbourne/art-and-design/article/frankies-mens-spin-smith-journal-hits-stands|title=Frankie's Men's Spin-Off, Smith Journal, Hits The Stands|work=Broadsheet|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en}}</ref> During its initial creation, ''Smith Journal'' was designed by ''frankie'' magazine's Creative Director, Lara Burke, with additional input from ''frankie's'' editor, Jo Walker and Senior Contributor, Benjamin Walker.<ref name=":1" /> However, Bannister was quick to point out that despite the similarities, "Smith is its own thing."<ref name=":4" />
== Launch == The first issue of ''Smith Journal'' was published in Australia on 5 September 2011. Frankie Press circulated 20,000 copies<ref name="adnews.com.au"/> of the first issue which contained 140 pages.<ref name=":2" />
When the magazine first launched in September 2011, it was during a period when a significantly large number of men's magazines were declining in sales and reader numbers. For example, ''FHM'' had posted a 20 percent drop from 2010 to 2011 to reach a record low of 40,000 circulated copies in Australia, and ''Zoo Weekly'' had dropped 18 percent to 83,000 circulated copies.<ref name=":5">{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/size-doesnt-matter-in-a-shrinking-market-mens-magazines-try-new-models-to-stay-on-top-20110813-1is6i.html|title=Size doesn't matter. In a shrinking market, men's magazines try new models to stay on top|last=Lallo|first=Michael|date=14 August 2011|work=The Age|access-date=2018-01-25|language=en-US}}</ref> Other men's titles such as ''Alpha, Sport & Style,'' and ''Ralph'' all folded in the same span of time.<ref name=":5" />'' ''
In response to the decision to launch a new men's magazine when a large number of others were closing, then editorial director Louise Bannister suggested ''Smith Journal'' was not intended to appeal to a mass audience, but instead to a smaller group of people interested in "something they can't get on the internet."<ref name=":5" />
== Readership == ''Smith Journal's'' readers are predominantly male, however, the magazine also holds a fairly sizable female reader base (70% male, 30% female).<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=http://www.smithjournal.com.au/media-kit|title=Media Kit|work=smithjournal.com.au|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-GB}}</ref> The magazine's media kit states that 58% of its readers are between 25–44 years old, and that 70% are university educated or are currently studying.<ref name=":6" />
Former editor Nadia Saccardo described the magazine's reader as curious and open-minded and that the content was designed to attract readers "who feel like they have been ignored, or would not traditionally pick up magazines."<ref name=":3" /> Editor-at-Large Rick Bannister elaborated on this statement by describing the magazine's average reader as someone who is creative and interested in reviving old traditions such as "brewing, or making furniture, or restoring bikes."<ref name=":1" />
Besides the quarterly issue, the magazine also features an online presence through its website ''smithjournal.com.au.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://smithjournal.com.au/|title=Australian Magazine in Blog Form {{!}} Smith Journal|website=smithjournal.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref> The website includes original articles and weekly blog posts not found in the magazine that cover a wider range of subjects and topics than the magazine usually focuses on. The website receives an average number of 19,900 unique visitors (six-month average), and 41,150+ average page views per month (media kit). ''Smith Journal'' also has an online shop where visitors can purchase individual copies (for domestic or international shipping), issues of the digital magazine, as well as past copies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.frankiepress.com.au/shop/|title=buy frankie magazine & Smith Journal magazine {{!}} frankie press|website=www.frankiepress.com.au|language=en|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>
== Staff == * '''Editor''' Chris Harrigan, previously Nadia Saccardo * '''Assistant Editor''' Taz Liffman * '''Designer''' Anjana Jain * '''Digital Director''' Suzi Taylor * '''Writers''' [[Mel Campbell]], Kane Daniel, Carl Dansk, [[The Bedroom Philosopher|Justin Heazlewood]], Koren Helbig, Christopher Hollow, Bryce Howorth, Marina Kamenev, Leta Keens, Brodie Lancaster, Ben McLeay, Stephin Merritt, Andrew Mueller, Max Olijnyk, Kieran Pender, Patrick Pittman, Justin Quirk, Luke Ryan, James Shackell, Rory Taggart, Alex Warren * '''Photographers''' Alice Aedy, Nicolas Blandin, Jeremy Bowtell, Jean-Marc Caimi, Carlos Chavarria, Chris Crerar, Elsie El-asmar, Daniel George, Mick Hutson, Charlie Kinross, Misha Petrov * '''Illustrators''' Indigo O'Rourke, Timothy Rodgers, George Wylesol * '''Notable contributors''': [[Dave Eggers]], [[Elizabeth Gilbert]], [[Tim Winton]]
== Contributors == ''Smith Journal'' has had a number of notable writers contribute to the magazine's content. [[Pulitzer Prize]]-winning writer and editor [[Dave Eggers]], author of popular novels ''[[A Hologram for the King]]'' and ''[[The Circle (Eggers novel)|The Circle]],'' contributed a personal narrative in the magazine's second issue.<ref name=":3" /> [[Elizabeth Gilbert]], author of ''[[Eat, Pray, Love]]'', has contributed an opinion piece on science and adventure.<ref name=":3" /> Australian writer [[Tim Winton]] had an article titled "10 Things I Believe" also published by the magazine.<ref name=":3" />
== References == <references />
== External links == * [http://www.smithjournal.com.au Official Smith Journal website] * [http://www.pacificstarnetwork.com.au/ Pacific Star Network website]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2015}} The '''Society for Art of Imagination''' ('''AOI''') is an international artists' society whose stated mission is to promote art of vision and craftsmanship. It has branches all over the world, and the American branch is a registered charity. AOI is affiliated with many other visionary art groups, including the [[Fantastic Art Centre]] in [[South Africa]]
AOI was founded in 1961 by a group of artists from England who called themselves the [[Inscape (visual art)|Inscape]] Group, among them [[Diana Hesketh]], [[Peter Holland (artist)|Peter Holland]], [[Brigid Marlin]], [[Jack Ray]] and [[Steve Snell (artist)|Steve Snell]]. Some of AOI's Honorary Art Members are [[Ernst Fuchs (artist)|Ernst Fuchs]], [[H R Giger]], [[Robert Venosa]], Martina Hoffmann, [[Alex Grey]], [[Laurie Lipton]], [[De Es]], [[Michel de Saint Ouen]], [[Otto Rapp]], [[Lukas Kandl]] and [[Ingo Swann]].
AOI holds annual art shows all over the world. AOI also publishes the magazine ''Inscape''. Artists are welcome to join. ==See also== *[[Fantastic art]] *[[Inscape (visual art)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.artofimagination.org Society for the Art of Imagination]
[[Category:Arts organizations established in 1961|Society for the Art of the Imagination, The]] [[Category:International artist groups and collectives|Society for the Art of Imagination, The]] [[Category:Fantastic art|Society for the Art of Imagination, The]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:Gold industry]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
The '''Society of Gilders''' (SoG) is an international [[non-profit organization]] dedicated to the practice and preservation of the art of using [[gold]] and [[metal leaf]]. SoG offers technical help for gilders, restorers, conservators, craftsmen, and all those interested in the [[gilding]] arts. Classes and conferences held by SoG bring gilders together from around the globe to learn, discuss and share.
Membership is open to any interested individual, institution or corporation.
==Mission== The Society of Gilders is a non-profit [[educational organization]] devoted to the art and craft of gilding. The society's mission is to preserve traditional gilding skills and techniques, and to promote the highest standards in the practice of gilding.
==History== A landmark event in the world of gilding took place at the [[Newark Museum]] in [[New Jersey]] during the winter of 1986. While attending a week-long gilding course hosted by the museum’s Arts Workshop, gilders met and exchanged gilding recipes, anecdotes, techniques and ethical concerns. The participants expressed a unanimous desire to extend this collaboration into an organization patterned after the ancient craftsmen’s guilds. Originally called the Guild of Gilders, the group changed their name to the Society of Gilders, welcoming fellow gilders and anyone interested in the art of gilding to join their ranks.
Today the Society of Gilders continues to grow, and the Regional Education Program continues to teach the art of gilding in many disciplines. Conferences have been held in [[Charleston, South Carolina|Charleston]], [[South Carolina]] (2000), [[Washington DC]] (2001, 2003, 2006 and 2008), and [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]] (2007 to 2013).
==Museum of Gilding Arts== The Society opened the Museum of Gilding Arts in [[Pontiac, Illinois]] in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Museum of the Gilding Arts to Open this Saturday in Pontiac, IL|url=http://www.rcreader.com/news-releases/the-museum-of-the-gilding-arts-to-open-this-saturday-in-pontiac-il/|publisher=River Cities Reader|accessdate=9 December 2015|date=June 5, 2015}}</ref> Displays include the history of gold beating, its use as a decorative element and a display of works of art by the Society's members.<ref>{{cite web|title=Museum of the Gilding Arts|url=http://il-pontiactourism.civicplus.com/2190/Museum-of-the-Gilding-Arts|publisher=Visit Pontiac Illinois|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref> There is also a recreation of the M. Swift & Sons factory, a gold leaf manufacturing company founded in [[Hartford, Connecticut]] in 1887.<ref>{{cite web|title=M. Swift & Sons Company|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/feature/places/13000527.htm|publisher=National Park Service: National Register of Historic Places Program|accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://societyofgilders.org Society of Gilders website]
[[Category:Gilding]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Crafts educators]] [[Category:Gold industry]]

revision.comment: added [[Category:1976 establishments in New York (state)]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox theatre group | name = Spiderwoman Theater | image = | imagesize = | caption = | formed = 1976 | disbanded = | genre = | location = [[Brooklyn, New York]] | members = | ArtisticDirector = Muriel Miguel | notable = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.spiderwomantheater.org/}} }} '''Spiderwoman Theater''' is an American, [[indigenous peoples|Indigenous]] women's [[Performance art|performance troupe]] that blends traditional art forms with Western theater. Their mission was to present exceptional theater performance, and to provide theatrical training and education in an urban Indigenous performance practice. The theater sprung out of the [[feminist movement]] in the 1970s. They questioned gender roles, cultural stereotypes, sexual and economic oppression.<ref name="mysite">{{cite web |title=About Spiderwoman Theater |url=https://www.spiderwomantheater.org/blank-mpvle |website=Spiderwoman Theater |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref> It was founded in 1976, the core of the group is formed by sisters Muriel Miguel, Gloria Miguel, and Lisa Mayo. It was the first [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] women's theater troupe and is named after the Spiderwoman deity from [[Hopi mythology]].<ref name=":0" />
==History== Muriel Miguel developed a piece with [[Lois Weaver]] based on three stories of the Hopi goddess [[Spider Grandmother|Spiderwoman]] teaching people how to weave. Miguel's sisters, Lisa Mayo and Gloria Miguel, joined the group.<ref name="AWSDTC">{{cite book|last1=Fliotsos|first1=Anne|last2=Vierow|first2=Wendy|chapter=Muriel Miguel|title=American Women Stage Directors of the Twentieth Century|date=2008|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Urbana|isbn=0-252-03226-8|pages=288–293|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EGOBtC_Jum0C&lpg=PA290&dq=%22spiderwoman%20theater%22&pg=PA289}}</ref>
Spiderwoman Theater was founded in 1976<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Women Artists of Color: A Bio-Critical Sourcebook to 20th Century Artists in the Americas|last=Farris|first=Phoebe|publisher=Greenwood Press|year=1999|isbn=0-313-30374-6|location=Westport, CT|pages=93}}</ref> and the group premiered their first work, ''Women in Violence'', at Washington Square Methodist Church. The play combined the actors' stories of violence, contrasting serious subject matter with slapstick and sexual humor. For the piece they created a simple lighting design and a backdrop made out of Native American quilts. They toured the play in the United States and Europe. At a theatre in [[Nancy, France]], the women refused to sweep their performance space before their show. Hecklers gathered at the performance, upset that a male producer had to sweep the floor. Organizers of a later performance in [[Bologna, Italy]] cancelled it for fear of riots.<ref name="AWSDTC"/>
Spiderwoman Theater debuted their second play, ''The Lysistrata Numbah!'', in 1977. The production melded [[Aristophanes]]' ''[[Lysistrata]]'' with group members' stories.<ref name="AWSDTC"/>
Schisms developed in the group that led to the theater dividing in two in 1981. The offshoot lesbian performance troupe [[Split Britches]] included Lois Weaver, [[Peggy Shaw]], and [[Deb Margolin]].<ref name="Peterson (1997)">{{cite book|last1=Peterson|first1=Jane T.|last2=Bennett|first2=Suzanne|title=Women Playwrights of Diversity: A Bio-bibliographical Sourcebook|date=1997|publisher=Greenwood Press|location=Westport, Connecticut|isbn=0-313-29179-9|pages=318–319|url=https://books.google.com.mx/books?id=rE1TrrghzLIC&lpg}}</ref> Spiderwoman Theater continued on with the three sisters and shifted its focus to Native American issues that year with the play ''Sun, Moon and Feather''.<ref name="AWSDTC"/> Spiderwoman Theater's ''Winnetou's Snake Oil Show from Wigwam City'' is a satire of the European and particularly [[Native American hobbyism in Germany|German fascination with Native Americans]]. The play parodies the characters of dime-store novelist [[Karl May]], [[New Age]]ism, and individuals who pretend to be Native American. The play includes a phony shaman workshop where white people are transformed into Indians for a weekend for $3000.<ref name="W&P"/> According to the troupe, it was an act of resistance meant to reclaim their identity as real Native Americans.<ref>Spiderwoman Theatre (1999). [http://hidvl.nyu.edu/video/000086266.html “Winnetou’s snake oil show from Wigwam City”]. ''Hemispheric Institute Digital Video Library''.</ref> After ''Winnetou's Snake Oil Show'', the sisters had enough remaining material they had been working on to have a new show, ''Reverb-ber-ber-rations''.<ref name="W&P">{{cite journal|last1=Burns|first1=Judy|last2=Hurlbutt|first2=Jerri|title=Secrets: A Conversation with Lisa Mayo of Spiderwoman Theater|journal=Women & Performance: A Journal of Feminist Theory|date=January 1992|volume=5|issue=2|pages=166–183|doi=10.1080/07407709208571158|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/07407709208571158?journalCode=rwap20#.VP5D7ctVK1E}}</ref>
Performance Documentation of the pieces "Women In Violence" (1976) and "Lysistrata Numbah!" (1977) were included in the WACK! Art and Feminist Revolution Exhibition, organized by Cornelia Butler and presented at The Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles, March 4-July 16, 2007.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/421897194|title=Wack! : Art and the feminist revolution : exposition présentée à Los Angeles, the Museum of Contemporary Art, du 4 mars au 16 juillet 2007|last=H.|first=Butler, Cornelia|last2=Calif.)|first2=Museum of contemporary art (Los Angeles,|date=2007-01-01|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=0914357999|oclc=421897194}}</ref> Additionally, Spiderwoman founder Muriel Miguel was the subject about a short documentary by [[Theatre Communications Group]] in a series about theatre companies about people of color.<ref>http://www.tcg.org/TheNext50Years/EDIInitiative/Legacy/News/MurielMiguelScreening.aspx</ref>
In 1997, a repository for Spiderwoman Theater, the [[Native American Women Playwrights Archive]] (NAWPA), was created. It contains promotional and personal documents associated with the theater troupe and also holds a collection of manuscripts and related items pertaining to Native American women in theater.
== Founders == Spiderwoman Theater was founded by sisters Muriel, Gloria Miguel and Lisa Mayo (born Elizabeth Miguel). They are of Kuna and Rappahannock ancestry and were born and grew up in Brooklyn, New York. The sisters' mother and maternal grandmother also grew up in Brooklyn, but their father, a Kuna Indian, was a born in the San Blas Islands near Panama. According to Muriel, their father struggled to provide for his family via conventional means, and so the family would perform dances and snake oil shows for money. The three sisters were embarrassed by these performances and decided they would rather associate with more professional types of theater as opposed to being "spectacles of cliché." <ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://spec.lib.miamioh.edu/home/nawpa-spiderwoman-theater/|title=NAWPA: Spiderwoman Theater {{!}} Miami University Libraries Steward & Sustain Department|website=spec.lib.miamioh.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-17}}</ref>
Muriel Miguel is a founder of the Native American Theatre Ensemble at [[La MaMa Experimental Theatre Club|La MaMa]].<ref name="AWSDTC" /> She is a choreographer, play writer, actor, educator, and [[Two-spirit]] woman. She gathered a diverse group of women including both of her sisters Gloria Miguel and Lisa Mayo, thus creating the Spiderwoman theater.<ref name="mysite"/> She also taught theater at Bard College. In addition to Spiderwoman Theater, she was a founding member of Joseph Chaikin's Open Theater.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ipl.org/div/natam/bin/browse.pl/A504|title=Muriel Miguel on Native American Authors|last=ipl2|website=www.ipl.org|access-date=2018-03-17}}</ref>
Gloria Miguel studied drama at Oberlin College.<ref name=":02" /> She has worked extensively in television and theater with the Spiderwoman, she has toured throughout New Zealand, Australia and Europe. She was a drama consultant for the Minnesota Native American AIDS, she was also a drama teacher at the YMCA eastern district in Brooklyn.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.spiderwomantheater.org/copy-of-muriel-miguel|title=About Muriel Miguel|website=|language=en|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref> she is also the mother of [[Monique Mojica]], another playwright and actress.
Lisa Mayo (1924-2013) was trained as a mezzo-soprano at the New York School of Music. Mayo also studied dance and musical comedy.<ref name=":02" /> She has written and performed in more than 20 plays that were produced by The Spiderwoman Theater, and toured New Zealand, Europe, Australia, China, United States and throughout Canada. She has created two one-woman shows ''The Pause That Refreshes'' and ''My Sister Ate Dirt.'' Mayo contributed to the Minnesota Native American AIDS by teaching theater crafts to young people. She served on the Board of Directors of [https://aich.org/ The American Indian Community House] from 1998-2007.<ref>{{cite web |title=About Gloria Miguel |url=https://www.spiderwomantheater.org/copy-of-gloria-miguel |website=Spiderwoman Theater |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref>
==Works== Of the many plays by Spiderwoman Theatre, the following plays have been printed in anthologies: * "Sun, Moon, and Feather" in ''Contemporary Plays by Women of Color: An Anthology''. Kathy A. Perkins and Roberta Uno, editors (London: Routledge, 1996. Republished in 2006). * "Power Pies" in ''Seventh Generation: An Anthology of Native American Plays''. Mimi D'Aponte, editor, (New York: Theatre Communications Group, June 1998). * "Winnetous Snake Oil Show from Wigwam City" in ''Playwrights of Color''. Meg Swanson and Robin Murray, editors, (Nicholas Brealey Publishing, Aug. 1999). * "Sun, Moon, and Feather" in ''Stories of Our Way: An Anthology of American Indian Plays''. Jaye T. Darby and [[Hanay Geiogamah]], editors, (UCLA American Indian Studies Center: Jan. 2000). * "Reverb-ber-ber-rations" in ''Staging Coyote's Dream: An Anthology of First Nation Drama in English''. Monique Mojica and Ric Knowles, editors (Playwrights Canada Press: Sept. 2002). * "Winnetou's Snake Oil Show from Wigwam City" in ''Keepers of the Morning Star: An Anthology of Native Women's Theater''. Jaye T. Darby and Stephanie Fitzgerald, editors (UCLA American Indian Studies Center: Jan. 2003). * "Winnetous Snake Oil Show from Wigwam City" in ''Footpaths & Bridges: Voices from the Native American Women Playwrights Archive''. Shirley A. Huston Findley and Rebecca Howard, editors ([[University of Michigan Press]]: 2009) * "Trail of the Otter" in ''Staging Coyote's Dream: An Anthology of First Nation Drama in English, Volume 2''. Monique Mojica and Ric Knowles, editors (Playwrights Canada Press: Sept. 2009). Other works include: * "Red Mother," a one-woman play produced for 2 nights at the Museum of the American Indian.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Douglas|first=Carol Anne|date=2008|title=Spiderwoman's "Red Mother"|jstor=20838935|journal=Off Our Backs|volume=38|issue=1|pages=79–80}}</ref> * "Persistence of Memory," a play about the healing aspects of story-telling as well as stereotypes surrounding Indigenous expressions and the challenges Indigenous performers face as a result.<ref>{{Cite book|jstor=10.7591/j.ctt7zg33.9|title=Mapping the Americas|date=2009|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=9780801448003|editor-last=Huhndorf|editor-first=Shari M.|edition=1|series=The Transnational Politics of Contemporary Native Culture|pages=105–139|doi=10.7591/j.ctt7zg33.9}}</ref> * ''Women in Violence'' 1977 * Lysistrata Numbah! 1977 * The Trilogy of: My Sister Ate Dirt, Jealousy and Friday Night 1978 * Cabaret: An Evening of Disgusting Songs and Pukey Images 1979 * Oh, What a Life 1980 * The Fittin' Room 1980 * Fear of Oatmeal, 2018: The day after "Fear of Oatmeal" closed, Muriel Miguel was named a recipient of a [[Doris Duke Performing Artist Award]] of $275,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.americantheatre.org/2018/06/26/muriel-miguel-and-rosalba-rolon-to-receive-2018-duke-awards/|title=Muriel Miguel and Rosalba Rolón to Receive 2018 Duke Awards|date=26 June 2018|publisher=|accessdate=15 November 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{multiple issues| {{one source|date=February 2015}} {{more citations needed|date=February 2015}} {{COI|date=February 2015}} }} {{Infobox company | name = Technip S.A. | logo = Technip.gif | type = [[S.A. (corporation)|Société Anonyme]] | successor = [[TechnipFMC]] | fate = merged with [[FMC Technologies]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[Doug Pferdehirt]] <small>([[CEO]])</small>|[[Thierry Pilenko]] <small>([[Executive Chairman]])</small>}} | industry = [[Engineering]] | products = [[Project management]], [[engineering]] and [[construction]] for the [[energy industry]] | revenue = {{increase}} €10.7 billion <small>(end 2014)</small><ref name="2014_results"/> | operating_income = {{decrease}} €825 million <small>(end 2014)</small><ref name="2014_results"/> | net_income = {{decrease}} €437 million <small>(end 2014)</small><ref name="2014_results"/> | assets = {{increase}} €14.6 billion <small>(end 2014)</small><ref name="2014_results"/> | equity = {{increase}} €4.4 billion <small>(end 2014)</small><ref name="2014_results"/> | num_employees = 37,500 <small>(July 2015)</small> | foundation = {{start date and age|1958}} | location = [[Paris]], [[France]] }}
'''Technip S.A.''' was a company that carries out [[project management]], [[engineering]] and [[construction]] for the [[energy industry]]; in 2017 it completed a merger with [[FMC Technologies]] to form [[TechnipFMC]]. Its headquarters were in the [[16th arrondissement of Paris|16th arrondissement]] of [[Paris]].<ref>"[http://www.technip.com/sites/default/files/technip/page/attachments/Plan_acces_TCS.pdf Access map]." Technip. Retrieved on {{date|26|December |2012}}. "89 avenue de la Grande Armée Paris 16"</ref> It has about 38,000 employees and operates in 48 countries.
== Overview == TECHNIP is primarily in the energy business and is active in three business segments, namely [[Subsea]], [[Offshore (hydrocarbons)|Offshore]] & [[Onshore (hydrocarbons)|Onshore]]. It has around 38,000 employees and operates in 48 countries. It owns a fleet of 21 vessels in operation with 6 more under construction. As of the end of 2014, while the operating income of Technip Group from recurring activities stood at ~ Euros 825 million, the total revenues stood at more than Euros 10.7 billion.<ref name="2014_results">[http://www.technip.com/sites/default/files/technip/fields/press/attachments/pr_fr_4qfy14_final.pdf Technip full Year 2014 results], sur "<Technip.com>".</ref>
== History == [[File:Technip HQ.jpg|thumb|Technip head office, 89 avenue de la Grande-Armée, Paris 16th arr.]] Technip was established in 1958 by IFP, [[Institut français du pétrole]], as Compagnie française d'études et de construction Technip.
In the 1960s, the company completed its first international projects in Africa and Asia. In the 1970s Technip became an international group with the acquisition of an office in Rome and the creation of Technip Geoproduction, a subsidiary specialized in hydrocarbon field equipment. During this period, Coflexip – a firm specialized in the design, manufacture and supply of flexible subsea flowlines – was created by the [[French Institute of Petroleum|IFP]] (French Petroleum Institute) and opened a flexible flowline manufacturing plant in Le Trait, France, as well as offices in [[Houston]], [[Aberdeen]] and [[Rio de Janeiro]].
In the 1980s Technip opened operating centers in Kuala Lumpur and Abu Dhabi. Coflexip opened a second flowline manufacturing plant in Brazil and branched out into the manufacture of umbilicals with the establishment of the Duco plant in Newcastle, UK.
Coflexip acquired Stena Offshore while Technip acquired several companies with strong technological expertise: ''Speichim'', ''Krebs'' and ''KTI''. Already established in the United States, KTI enabled Technip to set up in [[North America]]. Coflexip established a presence in Australia and acquired the Norwegian company Stena Offshore.
In the 2000s, Technip merged with Coflexip, which had just acquired Aker Maritime's Deepwater Division. The unified group is now one of the top five companies worldwide in engineering, technology and services for the energy industry. Many major contracts are signed, notably in the Middle East in the liquefied natural gas (LNG), ethylene and refining sectors.
In 2010 three major assets came into operation: the Technip fleet expanded to 17 vessels with the addition of the Apache II, one of the most advanced pipelay vessels in the industry, and the Skandi Vitoria, a Brazilian-flagged vessel dedicated to the pre-salt market. Asiaflex Products, the Group’s third flexible pipe production plant, located in Tanjung Langsat, Malaysia was inaugurated.
In 2011, Technip acquired Global Industries, substantially expanding its addressable market in subsea.
In 2012 Technip acquired [[Stone & Webster|Stone & Webster Process Technologies]] and associated oil and gas engineering capabilities from [[The Shaw Group]].
== <small>FMC-Technip Merger to Create $13 Billion Oil-Services Firm</small><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/fmc-technologies-technip-agree-to-13-billion-oil-services-merger-1463641987|title=FMC-Technip Merger to Create $13 Billion Oil-Services Firm|last=Williams|first=Selina|date=2016-05-19|last2=Landauro|first2=Inti|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.technipfmc.org|title=TechnipFMC|website=TechnipFMC|access-date=2016-11-28}}</ref> == In 2017, FMC Technologies Inc. and French oil-services Technip SA agreed to merge, forming a significant new player in an energy industry racked by a nearly two-year slump in crude prices.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://fuelfix.com/blog/2017/01/17/technipfmc-launches-as-newly-merged-offshore-giant/|title=TechnipFMC launches as newly merged offshore giant {{!}} Fuel Fix|website=fuelfix.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-19}}</ref>
The all-share deal would result in a new company named [[TechnipFMC]] with a market value of about $13 billion.
TechnipFMC has three [[headquarters]] in [[Houston]], [[Paris]] and [[London]] under new Houston-based CEO Doug Pferdehirt, who worked as FMC’s [[chief operating officer]]. Former Technip chairman and CEO Thierry Pilenko is the new executive chairman.<ref name=":0" />
== Listings == In the 1990s Technip was listed on the [[Paris Stock Exchange]] and Coflexip on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. Technip was included in the CAC40 French benchmark index in September 2009.
== Controversies == In June 2010 Technip S.A. agreed to pay a $338 million criminal penalty to resolve charges related to the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) for its participation in a decade-long scheme to bribe Nigerian government officials to obtain engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contracts.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703964104575334962621807130 | title=France's Technip Settles U.S. Bribery Charges | accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref>
In 2011, the US Securities & Exchange Commission (SEC) filed a lawsuit in the federal Southern District of New York alleging insider trading.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-09-20/sec-alleges-insider-trading-in-global-industries-technip-deal | title=Bloomberg Business: SEC Alleges Insider Trading | accessdate=18 February 2015}}</ref>
==Organization== Technip was certified as one of the first five companies in the world as a Global Top Employer 2015 which recognizes first-class employee offerings globally and equally. This independent certification delivered by the Top Employers Institute demonstrates the quality and consistency of the company’s human resources policies and practices all around the globe.
Technip has also been certified as a top employer in 24 countries (Australia, Brazil, China, Colombia, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Malaysia, Mexico, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Qatar, Russia, Singapore, Spain, Thailand, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States, Venezuela and Vietnam) as well as in three regions (Asia-Pacific, Europe and Latin America).<ref>[http://www.top-employers.com/companyprofiles/FR/technip-france/ Technip certified Top Employers in 24 countries and 3 regions] sur "<''www.top-employers.com''>".</ref>
In July 2015, it was announced that the company would lay off 6,000 employees due to the industry downturn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/fastft/355561/frances-technip-layoff-6000-amid-oil-swoon|title=Financial Times|date=July 7, 2015}}</ref>
== Financial and stock market information ==
{| class="wikitable" |+ Key Figures in millions of € ! Years ! 2006 ! 2007 ! 2008 ! 2009 ! 2010 ! 2011 ! 2012 ! 2013 ! 2014 |- | Revenue | 6,926.5 | 7,886.5 | 7,481.4 | 6,456.0 | 6,081.9 | 6,813.0 | 8,203.9 | 9,336.1 | 10,724.5 |- | Operating income from recurring activities | 333.2 | 247.0 | 656.9 | 676.7 | 620.3 | 709.5 | 821.7 | 844.5 | 825 |- | Net income | 201.9 | 128.0 | 454.3 | 170.4 | 417.6 | 507.3 | 539.7 | 563.1 | 436.6 |}
The Technip share is listed on Euronext Paris and on the American over-the-counter market.
* ISIN: FR0000131708 * Nominal value: euro
{| class="wikitable" |+ ! Years (at 12/31) ! 2008 ! 2009 ! 2010 ! 2011 ! 2012 ! 2013 ! 2014 |- | Number of outstanding shares(in millions) (a) | 109 | 109 | 110 | 111 | 113 | 113 | 114 |- | Market capitalization (in € millions) (Figures at the closing trade date) | 2,380 | 5,400 | 7,600 | 8,040 | 9,816 | 7,941 | 5,631 |}
The Technip share is included in the [[Dow Jones Sustainability Index]] and the Low Carbon 100 index and the ASPI Eurozone.

{{Infobox company | name = Tele München Gruppe | logo = Logo Tele München Gruppe.svg | logo_size = 250px | type = GmbH & Co. KG | foundation = 27 April 1970 | location = [[Munich]] | key_people = Herbert G. Kloiber
Herbert L. Kloiber | num_employees = | industry = Media | products = | revenue = €286 million{{cite web | url=http://www.tmg.de/de/media-relations/news/news-details/news/tmg-geschaeftsjahr-2015/?tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail | title=TMG financial year 2015 | author= | date=20 July 2016 | website= | publisher=TMG | language= | accessdate=25 January 2017}} | revenue_year = 2015 | operating_income = €56 million | income_year = 2015 | homepage = [http://www.tmg.de/de/home/ www.tmg.de] }} The '''Tele München Gruppe''' (TMG) is a [[Media (communication)|media]] company based in [[Munich]]. The activities of the TMG include trade in [[license]]s, investments in television and radio stations and distribution and production of [[television film]]s and [[film|movies]]. TMG has one of the largest film libraries in Europe.{{cn|date=June 2018}} == History == {{refimprove-section|date=June 2018}} [[File:Tmg-haus.jpg|thumb|Headquarters of TMG in Munich]] The ''Tele München GmbH'' was founded on April 27, 1970 by author and producer [[Walter Ulbrich]]. It was purchased in 1977 by Herbert Kloiber and his business partner Fritz Buttenstedt. In 1980 the ''[[Concorde Filmverleih]]'' (Concorde film distribution) was founded and a year later, in 1981, the company acquired along with the cinema operator Hans-Joachim Flebbe several movie theaters in [[Hamburg]], [[Berlin]] and [[Braunschweig]]. 1985 TMG was partner at the television station [[Sat.1]], but after a year sold its shares, and started the TV station ''musicbox''. In the same year TMG took over the Munich private radio station ''Radio Xanadu'', which was later renamed to [[NRJ Group|Radio Energy]]. In 1987, [[Silvio Berlusconi]]’s company [[Fininvest]] acquired 50 percent of ''musicbox''. This was the basis for the channel [[Tele 5]]. In 1988, [[Axel Springer SE|Axel Springer Publishing House]] and [[RTL Group|CLT]] became partner at TMG. In 1989, 50 percent from the company were sold to [[American Broadcasting Company|Capital Cities / ABC]]. 1991 TMG sold its shares in Tele 5 to the Axel Springer Publishing House and in 1992 founded, together with CLT, [[Bertelsmann]], [[Bauer Media Group]] and [[The Walt Disney Company]], the TV channel [[RTL II]]. In 1995, the television station [[Tm3]] was founded by TMG and the Bauer Media Group.{{cite web | url=http://info.rtl2.de/unternehmen/gesellschafterstruktur | title=Gesellschafterstruktur | author= | date= | website= | publisher=RTL II | language=German | accessdate=5 June 2015}} In 1996, Herbert Kloiber bought back the TMG shares from Capital Cities / ABC, and took over the shares of Bauer Media Group on Tm3. In 1997, TMG participated in the Hungarian private broadcaster [[TV2 (Hungary)|TV2]].{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2001/tv/news/tele-munchen-revs-hit-194-mil-on-record-sales-1117796630/ | title=Tele Munchen revs hit $194 mil on record sales | author=Ed Meza | date=6 April 2001 | website= | publisher=Variety | language= | accessdate=5 June 2015}} In 1998, [[Rupert Murdoch]]'s company [[News Corporation]] took over 66 percent of Tm3 and two years later, in 2000, took over Tm3 completely.{{cite web | url= https://www.handelsblatt.com/archiv/kloiber-plant-neuen-sender-tele-muenchen-gruppe-mit-rekordgewinn-nach-tm3-verkauf/2055474.html | title= Tele-München-Gruppe mit Rekordgewinn nach tm3-Verkauf | author= | date=5 April 2001 | website= | publisher=Handelsblatt | language=German | accessdate=}} On 28 April 2002, the channel Tele 5 was restarted by TMG. == Investments == === Sales === * TM Distribution * TM International * Concorde Filmverleih (Munich) * Concorde Home Entertainment (Munich) * CTM Concept-TV & Merchandising (Munich){{cite web | url=http://www.tmg.de/tmg/index.php?websiteLang=en | title=Activities | author= | date= | website= | publisher=Tele München Gruppe | language= | accessdate=5 June 2015}} === Broadcasting === * RTL II (Munich, 31.5%) * [[Tele 5]] (Munich, 100%) * [[ATV (Austria)|ATV]] ([[Vienna]], 48%) * ATV2 === Production === * Clasart Film (Munich) * Clasart Television * Clasart Classic * Prisma Entertainment Production === Other interests === * CineMedia Film AG (post-production) * Odeon Film{{cite web | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/herbert-kloibers-tele-munchen-group-264945 | title=Herbert Kloiber's Tele-Munchen Group Ups Stake in Odeon Film | author=Scott Roxborough | date=22 November 2011 | website= | publisher=The Hollywood Reporter | language= | accessdate=5 June 2015}} * On Demand Deutschland == See also == * [[ATV (Austria)]] * [[Bauer Media Group]] * [[Bertelsmann]] * [[Tm3]] * [[TV2 (Hungary)|TV2]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://www.tmg.de/tmg/index.php?websiteLang=en www.tmg.de] {{DEFAULTSORT:Tele Munchen Gruppe}} [[Category:Media companies of Germany]] [[Category:Media in Munich]] [[Category:Film industry]] '''Test Valley Arts Foundation''' (TVAF) is an independent grant giving charity established in 1991 by [[Michael Colvin]] MP with help from [[TESCO]] and [[Test Valley Borough Council]]. Since its inception TVAF has distributed some £75,000 in grants, awards, bursaries and underwriting to individual artists and arts organisations throughout the Test Valley.
In addition to helping groups and organisations, the foundation seeks to encourage and assist the development of talented individuals resident in the [[borough]] of [[Test Valley]].
==External links== *[http://www.testvalleyarts.org Official web site]

revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{POV|date=May 2017}} [[File:Francesco Porzio, Monumento alla difesa di Casale, Piazza Castello, Casale Monferrato (Ian Spackman 199xC n25).jpg|thumb|200px|Bronze of a young female warrior in [[Lombards|Lombard]] costume. Francesco Porzio, ''Monumento alla difesa di Casale'', 1897]] A '''virago''' is a woman who demonstrates exemplary and heroic qualities. The word comes from the Latin word ''virāgō'' (([[genitive case|genitive]] virāginis) meaning variously 'a man-like, vigorous, heroic maiden, a female warrior, heroine..'{{L&S|virago|virāgō|ref}} from ''vir'' meaning 'man' (cf. [[virile]] and [[virtue]]) to which the suffix ''-āgō '' is added, a suffix that creates a new noun of the [[Third declension|third declension]] with feminine [[grammatical gender]]. The word ''virago'' has almost always had an association with cultural [[gender role|gender transgression]]. A virago, of whatever excellence, was still identified by her gender. There are recorded instances of viragos (such as [[Joan of Arc]]) fighting battles, wearing men's clothing, or receiving the [[tonsure]].Jane Tibbetts Schulenburg. ''Forgetful of their sex: female sanctity and society, ca. 500-1100''. University Of Chicago Press, 2001. Page 50. {{ISBN|978-0-226-74054-6}}. The word ''virago'' could also be used disparagingly, to imply that a virago was not excellent or heroic, but was instead violating cultural norms. Thus ''virago'' joined [[pejorative]]s such as ''[[termagant]]'',{{Cite web| url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/virago| title=Virago| accessdate=2011-11-25| publisher=Merriam-Webster Online}} ''mannish'', ''amazonian'' and ''[[Shrew (archetype)|shrew]]'' to demean women who acted aggressively or like men. ==History== Historically, the concept of a virago reaches back into antiquity where [[Hellenistic philosophy]] asserted that elite and exceptionally heroic men had ''[[virtus (virtue)|virtus]]'' ({{lang-el|ἀνδρεία|andreia}}). ''Virtus'' (once again linked to ''vir'', the brave man abiding by society's highest values and ethics as opposed to ''homo'', human being) defined the traits of excellence for a man in ancient Rome (and Greece), including valor and heroism, but also morality and physical strength. Women and non-elite or unheroic men (slaves, servants, craftsmen, merchants) were considered a lesser category, and believed to be less excellent in [[Mos maiorum|Roman morality]]. A woman, however, if exceptional enough could earn the title ''virago''. In doing so, she surpassed the expectations for what was believed possible for her [[gender]], and embodied masculine-like aggressionVirginia Blanton. ''Signs of devotion: the cult of St. Æthelthryth in medieval England, 695-1615'' Pennsylvania State Univ Pr (Trd) (April 30, 2007). Page 168. {{ISBN|978-0-271-02984-9}}. and/or excellence. Virago, then, was a title of respect and admiration. In [[Christianity]], a [[nun]] or holy woman who had become equal in divinity to male [[monks]] through practiced [[celibacy]], exemplary religious practice and devotion, and intact [[virginity]], was considered to have surpassed the limitations of her femaleness and was called ''virago''.Newman, Barbara. ''From Virile Woman to Woman Christ: Studies in Medieval Religion and Literature''. University of Pennsylvania Press, 1995. Page 5. {{ISBN|978-0-8122-1545-8}}.Laurence Lux-Sterritt. Redefining Female Religious Life: French Ursulines And English Ladies in Seventeenth-Century Catholicism. Ashgate Pub Co (January 30, 2006). Page 61. {{ISBN|978-0-7546-3716-5}}. Firmicus Maternus describes virago as women who take on a man's character and desire intercourse with women like men.{{Cite book|title=Love Between Women: early Christian responses to female homoeroticism|last=Brooten|first=Bernadette|publisher=The University of Chicago Press|year=1996|isbn=978-0-226-07591-4|location=Chicago|pages=135}} Standard modern dictionaries define ''virago'' as either, in order of definition, (1) a "loud overbearing woman"; a "shrew".{Merriam-Webster's Third New International Dictionary of the English Language Unabridged, Copyright (c) 1993 Merriam-Webster, Incorporated, first definition of "virago"} or (2) a woman of "great stature, strength, and courage"http://www.answers.com/topic/virago Thus virago continues to be associated with both the naming of a woman who has either (1) a domineering, abrasive and spiteful manner, or (2) has risen above cultural and [[sexism|gender stereotypes]] to embody a [[virility|virile]] heroism; for example, the [[British Royal Navy]] christened at least four warships ''[[HMS Virago|Virago]]''. ==Vulgate Bible== The [[Vulgate]] Bible, translated by [[Jerome]] and others in the 4th century C.E., was an early Latin translation of the Hebrew Bible [[Hebrew Bible|Old Testament]]. In Genesis 2:23, Jerome uses the words ''Vir'' for man and ''Virago'' for "woman" attempting to reproduce a pun on "male" and "female" (''ish'' and ''ishah'') that existed in the Hebrew text.Saint Jerome, Robert Hayward. ''Saint Jerome's Hebrew questions on Genesis.'' Oxford University Press, USA (August 10, 1995) Page 113. {{ISBN|978-0-19-826350-0}}Helen Kraus. ''Gender Issues in Ancient and Reformation Translations of Genesis 1-4.'' Oxford University Press, USA (December 17, 2011). Page 182. {{ISBN|978-0-19-960078-6}} The Vulgate reads:
''Dixitque Adam hoc nunc os ex ossibus meis et caro de carne mea haec vocabitur '''virago''' quoniam de viro sumpta est.''
"And Adam said: This now is bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called woman, because she was taken out of man."
The Middle English poem ''[[Cursor Mundi]]'' retains the Latin name for the woman in its otherwise Middle English account of the creation:
''Quen sco was broght be-for adam, '''Virago''' he gaf her to nam; þar for hight sco '''virago''', ffor maked of the man was sco.'' (lines 631–34)
"When she was brought before Adam, Virago was the name he gave to her; Therefore she is called Virago, For she was made out of the man."
